stem: The nurse is preparing to administer insulin to a client during the morning rounds. Based on the pharmaceutical data, match each type of insulin to its correct onset and peak characteristics.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:30: Client (42-year-old female) with Type 1 Diabetes. Fingertip glucose is 242 mg/dL.
07:45: Breakfast tray is on the unit and will be served in 15 minutes.
08:00: Client is scheduled for Insulin Lispro (sliding scale) and Insulin Glargine (basal).
08:15: Client also has an order for Insulin NPH to be given before she goes to physical therapy later this afternoon.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
1. Insulin Lispro: Subcutaneous, AC (Before meals) and bedtime.
2. Insulin Regular: Subcutaneous, per provider order.
3. Insulin NPH: Subcutaneous, BID (08:00, 18:00).
4. Insulin Glargine: Subcutaneous, once daily at bedtime.

rationale.correct: Rapid-acting insulin (Lispro) has the quickest onset (<15 mins). Short-acting (Regular) onset is 30-60 mins with a peak at 2-4 hours. Intermediate (NPH) peaks much later (4-12 hours). Long-acting (Glargine) is peakless and maintains a steady state for 24 hours.
clinicalPearls: Rapid-Acting: '15 minutes feels like an hour during 3 rapid years' (15m onset, 1hr peak, 3hr duration).
Short-Acting: 'Short-staffed nurses went from 30 patients to 2, then 8' (30m onset, 2hr peak, 8hr duration).
Never mix Glargine (Lantus) in the same syringe with any other insulin.

questionTrap.trap: Mixing up the peak of Regular (2-4h) with NPH (4-12h).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that NPH is 'Not Pretty Hasty' - it takes its time to peak and lasts longer.
